exercise.p: Consider the expression (x + 2)(x - 5). Describe the "big picture" perspective of the expression and put boxes around the terms as appropriate.
Consider the expression x + 2(x - 5). Describe the "big picture" perspective of the expression and put boxes around the terms as appropriate.

aside.p: Many students treat this calculation like the previous one. It's an easy "gotcha" problem to catch students that aren't paying attention.

exercise.p: Determine whether you think the following equation is valid. Explain your reasoning.

aside.p: Hint: This is one of the special named functions that was discussed in this chapter.

exercise.p: Solve the equation x \ln(2) + 3 = -4. Do it once using a substitution for then do it without a that substitution. Use a complete presentation both times.
Consider the expression 2x(x - 3) + 4. Describe the "big picture" perspective of the expression and put boxes around the terms as appropriate.
Evaluate the expression 2x(x - 3) - 5 when x = 2. Use a complete presentation.

aside.p: There are no examples of this! Use your best judgment of what a "complete presentation" would like for this calculation based on your experience. Start trusting yourself.

exercise.p: Consider the expression (x + 1)^2 - (x - 1)^2. Describe the "big picture" perspective of the expression and put boxes around the terms as appropriate.
Simplify the expression (x + 1)^2 - (x - 1)^2 using a complete presentation.
Solve the equation 2 \tan(x) - 5 = -3 for Do it once using a substitution for then do it without that substitution. Use a complete presentation both times.
Solve the equation ax + b = c for the variable using a complete presentation.
Solve the equation 2 \log(x) = \log(x) + 5 for Do it once using a substitution for then do it without that substitution. Use a complete presentation both times.

aside.p: Students can start to feel lost with a problem like this. But the substitution helps them to visually identify where the variable terms are located, and it helps them to see how to proceed.

Solve the equation x\sin(1) + \cos(2) = x \ln(3) - f(4). Use a complete presentation.

aside.p: Try to do this without making substitutions.
